children.subject: Yes

If it’s not dropped as a requirement can we be assured that more seats will be added for LnS undeclared because currently there are only like 5 seats for LnS undeclared and a majority are reserved for EECS?
<md>Good idea!  Done.</md>
An instructor should pin this imo
yes
Yes, either way typically what happens is the change is for the new incoming class and beyond
That is not correct. Change starts next semester means as in Fall 2022. It doesn’t mean it’s for people admitted after then. Just want to clarify
I will be a junior next semester. Should I still enroll 16B in phase 1?

No one was ever forced to enroll in that class; it came down to your personal choice and judgment. Many of us who were also upperclassmen decided to not enroll in EE16B last semester and this semester as we genuinely viewed the class as a significant deadweight to our intended careers. We firmly believed in the removal of such a requirement. Enrolling in such a class early on indicates that the class is at least somewhat relevant to you, and those who achieved their desired results in that class last semester would never complain about receiving a P/NP option to cover up their grade or to wipe the course off of their transcript. It is thus reasonable that the pending decision is only effective for future semesters, and we won't be able to make accommodations for those who did not achieve a result they desired for a course taken in a past semester.
Not literally forced, although these people were misinformed.
That is such cap, i'll be right back
This was after a sp21 NP

Again, many of us upperclassmen were given the same message about EE16B that semester, but it was clear they were doing so knowing the excessive lack of interest in the not-so-relevant contents of EE16B would reasonably compel many CS students to delay taking this class as much as possible, in favor of the more useful and relevant courses such as CS170/162/189/161/etc. As a result, many of us stood firmly against taking EE16B in spite of such claims, and instead took classes that were much more relevant to our careers. If you eventually decided to enroll in EE16B that semester, it implies that the class is more relevant to you than the many of those who decided not to enroll, and thus you will have to take responsibility for your own personal choice and judgment. No student was ever forced into EE16B, and I guarantee that those who actually worked hard in the class and ended up with their desired grade that semester would never complain and ask to wipe the class off of their transcript. We acknowledge that our department isn't perfect, and that is why we are continually striving towards bettering the quality of our education through making improvements, such as removing the EE16B requirement.
??? I can only afford my 8 semesters of college. How does my situation fit in your logic?

@Helix no need to bootlick; it's clear students were actively being pressured by the department to take the class as soon as possible, which if removed as a requirement for them to graduate can be considered disingenuous. In fact, I know multiple students who were quite literally forcibly enrolled into the class against their will (I believe this was Spring 2021, perhaps Fall 2021 as well). And it's not about "hard work" - the class is riddled with problems from head-to-toe that can be easily considered barriers to success regardless of effort and interest level.

> I guarantee that those who actually worked hard in the class and ended up with their desired grade that semester would never complain and ask to wipe the class off of their transcript.

Pretty toxic take, not to mention what's been going on in the world for the past two years.

I don't wanna be rude or offensive, but I have to say @Helix's statement is ignorant and condescending. I took 16B last semester, aced both midterm and final, and got an A+ in the end. But I would say this class is completely irrelevant to my field, and I have learned all the class materials in other classes before (ofc except for circuits cuz it is irrelevant to my field lmao). Nonetheless, I still took 16B because I don't want to take the risk of not being able to graduate with my LSCS major AS DEPARTMENT EMPHASISED FOR SEVERAL TIMES! Because 16B has such a high workload, I have to sacrifice the chance of taking a statistics class that is very interesting and important to me but is only offered every Fall! I could've taken a class that can actually broaden my skills and views that can help me more in finding research and interns instead of learning something I've already known.

I don't really get what did @Helix even mean by "No one was ever forced to enroll in that class; it came down to your personal choice and judgment". In such an asymmetric information scenario, where the department has control of everything, clearly, the best strategy is to listen to the department's words. You're not doing so because you are willing to gamble with your life, whereas the majority of us are not. If the department is really doing what they USED TO CLAIM, then you should be crying right now.
So, will the department ever give us a clear response? This is pathetic. We're getting gaslit by our own professors.
Ex: 16B TA ModCheck. Professors are human as well. Decisions take time. I was a CS major who didn't have to take EE 16B but found that it saved my life.
@Taejin L + ratio

If they go ahead and remove it as a requirement, what happens to people who were force-enrolled in Fall 2021? We never got the PNP option, were told it was a requirement, were threatened by the administration with delayed graduation, and then the department turns around and removes it? Sounds like we should've ignored the department's mandate? That seems backward and super arbitrary, especially seeing as the two semesters before AND the semester after, a PNP option that fulfilled the requirement was provided.
Probably not until after May 4, since "Our understanding is the L&S Executive Committee plans to discuss this matter at their May 4th meeting."
By when will we know if the requirement has been officially removed?
Following

Why can't we just be given a date when the decision will be finalized- why does there have to be an undercurrent of anxiety and stress surrounding just about everything EECS-related. 

I understand that this may not be in the department's control, but it's just discouraging that students in this major always have things to stress about- whether it be the ability to declare, then after declaring the ability to enroll in classes, then after enrolling the ability to actually get the resources they need to succeed, and the list seems to go on and on... Perhaps this stress is also experienced by admin, who simply lack the resources to be able to fix these issues- but nonetheless it certainly is not conducive to a good educational experience at Cal. 

Sorry for the rant :/

Also, I believe that there are a lot of students who want to take classes that they really want or need, but because they have to enroll in 16b, they cannot use phase 1 units for important classes and might lose the chance to take those classes because of limited number of open/waitlist seats.

Please I need to know to drop 16b in the summer. Summer tuition is a lot more pricey this year. That, or they're giving much less financial aid because I enrolled in fewer units but was changed 2.5x more compared to last summer.

If someone in the department could say something, anything that'd be helpful. Because, my entire schedule for next semester depends on this decision, and I am unable to enroll in anything else, unless I know the outcome of this decision for phase 1.

The longer they drag this on, the less likely they will keep the EE16B requirement. So at this point, if you are forced to make a decision regarding course enrollment, the best bet would be to assume that the 16B requirement has already been dropped. My friends and I decided to not enroll in 16B just so we can use our Phase 1 space for the more important upper-div classes. So if 16B is indeed a useless class for you (which is the case for 99% of L&S CS majors), then don't bother enrolling in it anymore. Of course, there are no guarantees either way, but this is the slightly more optimal choice here given how long they have delayed this decision since the initial announcement.

As @Anonymous Gear 2 said, students deserve to know a final date when decisions are released and receive more transparent communication about what's causing delays for this decision to be released. This would help us make decisions about future course schedules and financial situations.

Even if the department decides to remove the 16B requirement, I feel like it will only be applied to future generations of LSCS students, i.e., those who haven't been declared as LSCS or haven't entered Berkeley. So my personal advice is to keep yourself enrolled in 16B.

The message given by the department strongly implies that the ultimate decision will be effective immediately for all students currently enrolled or otherwise, not to mention those who took 16B this semester had the choice to P/NP or even late-drop had the school announced a decision just a bit earlier. Again, the CS department has already decided to remove the EE 16B requirement and they are just waiting for the L&S college to formally approve the removal simply as an administrative step.

Given that the decision will be announced by the end of this semester, it wouldn't make sense to apply the new policy toward only those who haven't yet entered the school. Doing so would exacerbate the already-existing negativity that many L&S CS majors have towards EE 16B, especially among those who are forced to take this class against their will and at the expense of their valuable time.
Where did you hear that the CS department has already decided to remove EE 16B requirement?
the fact that CS sent their decision to remove 16b to L&S for approval
Any update from that May 4th meeting?
Same here, this is definitely nerve wracking since we aren't getting a set date. I would think that since this affects our immediate schedules, this would be a top priority :/

It is extremely frustrating for this reason, you would think that the department would be quick to react when students are paying a lot of money to take this class and are centering their schedules around this class, but I guess not.  I fell as if they should give us a decision before the Summer 22 drop deadline for 16B so students can get their money back if needed or stay in the class if they so desire.
I have never followed a piazza post so closely or checked to see if it's gotten answered so often
Amen brother.
Would really appreciate if we have an answer on this since summer course fees are due soon!
Could we get an answer on this?  There is money on the line for a lot of students, or maybe that is the point......

Can we have an answer on the final resolution of 16B requirement before summer sessions begin? This is a pressing issue for many students' academic planning and paths.

It has been over a month since the original planned announcement date (April 9th). This has been nerve wracking for the past month.
nah you tweakin
Trust that professors are working on it. Decisions take time. If you ever need help, reach out.

<md>TLDR - I think it is only fair to consider P/NP grading for those who took EECS16B prior to Spring 2022, particularly those who did in Fall 2021. What is it that justifies the denial of switching to a P/NP grading option for students who happened to take EECS16B in Fall 2021 and allows Spring 2022 and any other semester prior to Fall 2021 up until the start of the pandemic to have this option ? I cannot find any logical reasoning, and I have been told that it is due to the lack of technical flexibility within CalCentral and how grades are maintained. If this is the case, then as an upcoming graduate from one of the "top" CS programs in the world, I openly volunteer my time to help the IT department employ this update for those who wish to change their grading option for EECS16B taken during the fall of 2021. 

Can somebody please help me understand the logic behind why the P/NP doesn't apply to Fall 2021 students? The EECS16B course is the one outlier on my transcripts and since I've had to basically reset my GPA as a transfer student, I am now in an unfavorable situation which seems to be the result of a lack in organization and/or funding.  As a CC Transfer student who transferred into my DREAM school at the peak of the pandemic, I've felt extremely let down throughout my experience here as I am now getting ready to graduate 2 years later.  To be quite frank, my entire experience at Berkeley has left me traumatized. This is a shame, because I was admitted to Stanford for my MSE but am so disgusted that I will most likely choose not to pursue a graduate degree. 

There has been so many disappointments throughout these two years and I wont go into further detail unless asked, but I just wanted to highlight that it's really unfortunate that our experiences were tainted as a result of poor structure. I'm glad theres alot of attention on this now, but the least we can do is help those who have endured the BS and made it this far. My passion is so deep and I truly feel I was robbed of the opportunity to engage in some really epic ground breaking research opportunities at Berkeley....IMO, the least the dept. can do is update this irrational policy so that we can atleast make it through the resume parsers companies use to filter out candidates without having to give some drawn out story about how my GPA reset upon transfer, and blah blah blah. Im not here for the paycheck, Im here for the impact and unfortunately some companies hold strict GPA thresholds.
</md>
lmao
Seems legitimate. Glad that the dark era of EE16B is finally over.
does this mean this will be effective for students graduating for fall 22?
Is this legitimate? No false news?
Faith in humanities restored! I had to drop 16B two weeks ago because my summer bill was too high. Glad that was the right choice.
<md>If you are unsure of its legitimacy, you can always email them to confirm (the email is in the screenshot you attached), and then report back here for others with the same concerns.</md>
If we took the class in a past semester, is there any mechanism to drop it after the fact?
Or if we took it in fa21, is there anyway we can drop it from our transcript?
Unfortunately that wouldn't be possible
Has anyone emailed them to check yet?
When will this be announced officially?

I went to drop in advising and they told me sometime next week. They’ll also be announcing that the proposal to decrease the technical elective units required from the current 7 units is also approved.

This has been said many times already, but it would be incredibly unfair if Fall 2021 16B students weren't allowed to drop it from their transcript, or at the very least retroactively P/NP. I would understand the current policy a bit more if they did not give us specific guidance on whether or not to take 16B in Fall 2021. However, we were literally told repeatedly in very long Piazza posts that we may not be able to graduate if we didn't take 16B that semester even if we didn't initially plan to do so.

I dedicate this victory against EECS16b to all those GPAs which did not live to see it.

And may they please forgive us for not having won it quick enough, nor having fought it hard enough.

Has anyone actually looked into the process of dropping classes from your transcript? I skimmed through the academic senate handbook and it seems to say

"All grades except Incomplete are final when filed by the instructor of record in an end-of-term course report. However, the correction of a clerical or procedural error may be authorized as the Division directs. No change of grade may be made on the basis of reassessment of the quality of a student’s work. No term grade except Incomplete may be revised by re-examination."

Seems like even if the department is willing, it's unlikely that university policy would allow something like retroactively P/NPing or dropping a class. I agree it's a pretty rough situation to be in, but it's more likely that you'll be heard if you can find a concrete course of action that's feasible given university policy.
So if I am graduating in Spring 2024, I can drop this class?
Yes
<md>Does this mean that if we took Math 54, we will not need to take 16A OR 16B? </md>
That's correct.
Got this from CS advising. Looks like the email was indeed legitimate!

Hi all,

The email in the screenshot was from my inbox. It is definitely legitimate haha.
Awesome! Thanks for confirming

They’ll also be announcing that the proposal to decrease the technical elective units required from the current 7 units is also approved. Anyone have info regarding this? Just so I could drop a summer course in Session A if I don't need it. Thanks!

I went to advising a month ago and they said they are reducing the count down. I don't remember if it was down to 4 units or some other number. I was also told that Math 53 would no longer count as a CS upper div technical elective.
Is this legitimate???
as an aside, 61C fulfills the physical science breadth, and is required for CS

CS61C and CS188 both count towards the physical science breadth; 61C is required for all CS majors and 188 is taken by most CS majors, so if you're in CS then there's no need to count EE16B as a breadth
I think a reasonable resolution would be for it to count as 3 units towards upperdiv requirements, similar to Math 53 but for EE/CS classes.

Yeah I agree that it should at least count for upperdiv requirements.  Thanks for letting me know about the physical science breadth being met by 61C. I thought that major requirements couldn't meet breadths, but I guess I was wrong.

If we are intended/declared L&S CS majors and took EECS 16b for a grade this semester, I was wondering if there is any way that it can count towards our breadth requirements? I feel like many cs students, including myself, do not plan on taking any other electrical engineering courses during their time at Berkeley. For me, this class was my first chance to explore the field and learn more about what it means to be an electrical engineer(I did not take EECS 16a but Math 54 in high school instead). Many other engineering courses are already included in the breadth system, so I think it makes sense that eecs16b should count as a physical sciences breadth for cs students if the major requirement is removed. Is it likely that something like this could happen? I would really like for my hard work in this class to count towards something other than a prerequisite for EE courses that I am not going to take.
Yes. You can just fill out a waiver form, and you will be good to go!
Where could I assess the waiver form?
You can go to advising for specifics on how to fill out the forms. However, I believe it's the following link: https://goo.gl/forms/RQsPCTp5SFTpfB4V2
Are there any updates for seniors graduating in Summer 2022 with EE16B as the only requirement left?
No
I was just thinking that... May I ask where you got that info @Helix? Thank you!!
so is there a different course we have to take instead of 16b

history.content:
You may be aware that the L&S Executive Committee is reviewing a proposal from EECS to change the EECS 16B requirement for the L&S CS major. Approval is not guaranteed. If the proposal is approved, any changes to the requirements for the L&S CS major will not take effect in the middle of a term. Following long-standing campus practice, any changes to degree requirements apply to future semesters only. Our understanding is the L&S Executive Committee plans to discuss this matter at their May 4th meeting.

Thus, we recommend the following courses of action:

  • Graduating L&S CS seniors should remain in EECS 16B. There is no possibility this proposal will affect your graduation requirements.

  • Other L&S CS students who are taking EECS 16B should continue in this course. Although there is some chance it will be removed as a requirement, definitive information in this regard is unlikely to be available before the end of this semester.  Note: The special P/NP grading accommodation for L&S CS applies only to EECS 16B in Spring 2022 and not in future semesters.

#pin
